media.caption: The RMS Titanic in Southampton on 10 April 1912 (\credits\)

text.headline: History of the Titanic and Harland & Wolff
text.text: Explore the pivotal events in the journey of the RMS Titanic and the Harland & Wolff shipyard.

media.caption: The Harland and Wolff Shipyard in Belfast (\credits\)

text.headline: Founding of Harland & Wolff Shipyard
text.text: Harland & Wolff was established in 1861 in Belfast, Northern Ireland, and became one of the largest shipbuilders in the world.

media.caption: The Olympic and Titanic in the Harland & Wolff shipyard under construction (\credits\)

text.headline: Construction of Titanic Begins
text.text: Construction of the RMS Titanic began in 1909 at the Harland & Wolff shipyard, alongside its sister ship, the RMS Olympic.

text.headline: Titanic Sets Sail
text.text: The RMS Titanic set sail from Southampton, UK, embarking on its maiden voyage across the Atlantic to New York City.

text.headline: Sinking of the Titanic
text.text: RMS Titanic, on its maiden voyage, sinks after hitting an iceberg, causing the deaths of over 1,500 passengers and crew.

text.headline: Titanic Inquiry Conclusion
text.text: The British inquiry into the Titanic disaster, led by Lord Mersey, concludes, emphasizing recommendations for improved maritime safety.

text.headline: Launch of HMS Belfast
text.text: Harland & Wolff launches HMS Belfast, which would become one of the most famous Royal Navy ships, now a museum ship in London.

text.headline: Launch of MV Arlanza
text.text: Harland & Wolff launches the MV Arlanza, signifying the shipyard's continued prominence in shipbuilding post-WWII.

media.caption: Staff Picture of Harland & Wolff Shipyard

text.headline: Team Picture
text.text: Harland & Wolff team poses for a goodbye retirment picture
